docs.title: GED Science Prep
docs.text: Welcome to the GED Science preparation resource! This comprehensive curriculum covers all 200 assessment targets required for the GED Science Test.

docs.title: About This Course
docs.text:
This course is designed for adult learners preparing for the GED Science Test. It covers:

  • 200 Concepts organized into 12 chapters
  • 8 Science Practices that reflect how scientists work
  • 3 Content Domains: Life Science, Physical Science, and Earth and Space Science
  • Interactive Learning through MicroSims and visualizations

docs.title: Course Structure
docs.text:
The curriculum is organized into 12 chapters:

  1. Scientific Reasoning Foundations
  2. Comprehending Scientific Materials
  3. Designing and Conducting Scientific Investigations
  4. Reasoning from Data and Evidence
  5. Statistical Methods and Sampling
  6. Descriptive Statistics and Probability
  7. Evaluating Scientific Claims and Theories
  8. Scientific Models and Theories
  9. Expressing and Communicating Scientific Information
  10. Life Science: Human Body and Health
  11. Life Science: Energy Flow and Cellular Organization
  12. Life Science: Genetics, Heredity, and Evolution

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Review the Course Description to understand the learning objectives
  2. Explore the Chapter Overview to see the complete structure
  3. Begin with Chapter 1: Scientific Reasoning Foundations

docs.title: Learning Graph
docs.text: The Learning Graph shows how all 200 concepts connect and depend on each other. This helps you understand prerequisite relationships and ensures you learn concepts in the right order.

docs.title: Interactive Elements
docs.text: Each chapter includes interactive MicroSims, diagrams, and charts to help visualize scientific concepts. These interactive elements make abstract concepts concrete and easier to understand.

docs.title: Assessment Preparation
docs.text:
This curriculum aligns with the GED Science Assessment Targets and prepares you for:

  • Multiple choice questions
  • Short answer questions
  • Data interpretation tasks
  • Scientific reasoning scenarios

Good luck with your GED Science preparation!

docs.title: Getting Started with GED Science Prep
Overview
docs.text: This guide will help you get started with the GED Science preparation materials.

docs.title: Course Structure
docs.text: The GED Science curriculum is organized into 12 chapters covering 200 concepts. Each chapter builds on previous concepts, so it's recommended to work through them in order.

docs.title: How to Use This Resource
docs.text:
1. Start with Chapter 1 - Scientific Reasoning Foundations establishes the core concepts you'll need
  2. Work through chapters sequentially - Concepts build on each other
  3. Use the Learning Graph - Check concept dependencies if you're unsure about prerequisites
  4. Interact with MicroSims - Visual and interactive elements help reinforce learning
  5. Review regularly - Revisit previous chapters to reinforce understanding

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By completing this course, you will be able to:

  • Comprehend scientific presentations (text, graphs, tables, diagrams)
  • Design scientific investigations
  • Reason from data and evidence
  • Evaluate scientific claims and theories
  • Express scientific information clearly
  • Apply scientific models and theories
  • Use probability and statistics
  • Integrate concepts across scientific disciplines

docs.title: Assessment Format
docs.text:
The GED Science Test includes:

  • 90 minutes to complete
  • 34-40 questions covering all content domains
  • 60% of questions at Depth of Knowledge (DOK) level 2 or 3
  • Questions may include text passages, graphs, charts, tables, and diagrams

docs.title: Study Tips
docs.text:
1. Take notes as you read each chapter
  2. Complete interactive exercises in the MicroSims
  3. Review the Learning Graph to see how concepts connect
  4. Practice with sample questions (when available)
  5. Focus on understanding rather than memorization

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Read the Course Description
  • Review the Chapter Overview
  • Begin Chapter 1: Scientific Reasoning Foundations

docs.title: GED Science Chapter Structure
docs.text: I've designed a 12-chapter structure covering all 200 concepts from the GED Science Assessment Targets.

docs.title: Chapter List
docs.text: Chapter Title Concepts Chapter 1 Scientific Reasoning Foundations 15 concepts Chapter 2 Comprehending Scientific Materials 18 concepts Chapter 3 Designing and Conducting Scientific Investigations 27 concepts Chapter 4 Reasoning from Data and Evidence 12 concepts Chapter 5 Statistical Methods and Sampling 8 concepts Chapter 6 Descriptive Statistics and Probability 18 concepts Chapter 7 Evaluating Scientific Claims and Theories 24 concepts Chapter 8 Scientific Models and Theories 21 concepts Chapter 9 Expressing and Communicating Scientific Information 15 concepts Chapter 10 Life Science: Human Body and Health 14 concepts Chapter 11 Life Science: Energy Flow and Cellular Organization 12 concepts Chapter 12 Life Science: Genetics, Heredity, and Evolution 16 concepts

docs.title: Chapter 1: Scientific Reasoning Foundations (15 concepts)
docs.text: Establishes the foundational concepts including Scientific Reasoning, the Scientific Method, Evidence-Based Reasoning, Data Interpretation, Scientific Literacy, and Scientific Inquiry. This chapter introduces the GED Assessment Targets framework and sets the stage for all subsequent learning.

docs.title: Chapter 2: Comprehending Scientific Materials (18 concepts)
docs.text: Covers reading and interpreting scientific texts, non-textual presentations, visual data representation, graphs, charts, tables, diagrams, and scientific vocabulary. Students learn to understand central ideas, identify trends, and use context clues in scientific communication.

docs.title: Chapter 3: Designing and Conducting Scientific Investigations (27 concepts)
docs.text: Comprehensive coverage of experimental design including hypothesis formation, variables (independent, dependent, controlled), sources of error, measurement tools, precision and accuracy, sample size, replication, experimental procedures, and comparing experimental designs.

docs.title: Chapter 4: Reasoning from Data and Evidence (12 concepts)
docs.text: Focuses on drawing evidence-based conclusions, citing textual evidence, numerical data analysis, data-driven reasoning, logical conclusions, scientific predictions, trend analysis and extrapolation, and understanding variable relationships.

docs.title: Chapter 5: Statistical Methods and Sampling (8 concepts)
docs.text: Introduces sampling techniques, random and systematic sampling, representative samples, sample bias, population vs sample distinctions, statistical inference, and sampling strategies essential for scientific research.

docs.title: Chapter 6: Descriptive Statistics and Probability (18 concepts)
docs.text: Covers descriptive statistics (mean, median, mode, range, standard deviation, variance), data distributions (normal and skewed), counting principles, permutations, combinations, and probability concepts including simple, compound, independent, and dependent events.

docs.title: Chapter 7: Evaluating Scientific Claims and Theories (24 concepts)
docs.text: Teaches evaluation of scientific claims, evidence supporting and challenging conclusions, theory evaluation, hypothesis testing, model validation, conflicting evidence, reproducibility, peer review, scientific consensus, paradigm shifts, and theory modification.

docs.title: Chapter 8: Scientific Models and Theories (21 concepts)
docs.text: Explores scientific models, theory definitions, laws vs theories, theory application, conceptual/mathematical/physical models, model limitations, theory-based predictions, formula application, and established theories including Cell Theory, Atomic Theory, Conservation Laws, and Genetic Principles.

docs.title: Chapter 9: Expressing and Communicating Scientific Information (15 concepts)
docs.text: Covers visual communication, creating graphs/tables/diagrams, chart types, numerical expression, mathematical and scientific notation, units and conversions, verbal communication, scientific writing, technical writing, data presentation, and information translation.

docs.title: Chapter 10: Life Science: Human Body and Health (14 concepts)
docs.text: Introduces human body systems (muscular, endocrine, nervous), system integration, homeostasis, feedback mechanisms, external environment effects, nutrition and nutrients, disease transmission, pathogens, and disease prevention.

docs.title: Chapter 11: Life Science: Energy Flow and Cellular Organization (12 concepts)
docs.text: Covers photosynthesis, cellular respiration, fermentation, energy flow in ecosystems, food webs and chains, producer-consumer relationships, carrying capacity, ecosystem disruption, Cell Theory, cell structure and function, cellular organization, and mitosis/meiosis.

docs.title: Chapter 12: Life Science: Genetics, Heredity, and Evolution (16 concepts)
docs.text: Final chapter covering Punnett squares, genetic probability, DNA and inheritance, chromosomes, genotypes and phenotypes, alleles, mutations, natural selection, artificial selection, adaptation, speciation, common ancestry, cladograms, evolution evidence, variation in traits, differential survival, and selection pressure.

docs.title: Learning Graph
docs.text: The learning graph shows how all 200 GED Science concepts connect and depend on each other. Understanding these relationships helps you learn concepts in the correct order and see how scientific knowledge builds systematically.

docs.title: Graph Structure
docs.text:
The learning graph is organized by:

  • Taxonomy Categories: Foundation Concepts, Comprehension, Investigation Design, Reasoning from Data, Evaluating Conclusions, Scientific Theories, Expression of Information, Probability & Statistics, and Life Science
  • Concept Dependencies: Shows which concepts must be learned before others
  • 200 Total Concepts: Covering all GED Science Assessment Targets

docs.title: Key Files
docs.text:
• Course Description - Overview of learning objectives
  • Concept Enumeration - Complete list of all 200 concepts
  • Learning Graph Data - Interactive visualization data
  • Quality Metrics - Graph structure analysis
  • Taxonomy Distribution - Concept categorization

docs.title: Using the Learning Graph
docs.text:
The learning graph helps you:

  1. Identify prerequisites - See what you need to know before learning a concept
  2. Understand relationships - See how concepts connect across different topics
  3. Plan your study - Follow the dependency structure for efficient learning
  4. Review connections - Understand how scientific knowledge is interconnected

docs.title: Interactive Visualization
docs.text:
The learning graph can be visualized using the graph viewer. Each concept is color-coded by its taxonomy category, and arrows show dependency relationships.

Open Interactive Graph Viewer — search, filter by category, and explore the full 200-concept graph.

docs.title: Course Description: GED Science Assessment Targets
Course Overview
docs.text: This course covers the fundamental assessment targets and practices for the GED Science Test, focusing on scientific reasoning, investigation design, data interpretation, and content knowledge across three major domains: Life Science, Physical Science, and Earth and Space Science.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
Upon completion, learners will be able to:

  1. Comprehend Scientific Presentations - Understand and analyze both textual and non-textual scientific materials including graphs, tables, and diagrams
  2. Design Scientific Investigations - Identify hypotheses, variables, sources of error, and create experimental designs
  3. Reason from Data - Draw conclusions from evidence, make predictions, and use sampling techniques
  4. Evaluate Scientific Claims - Assess whether conclusions are supported or challenged by evidence
  5. Express Scientific Information - Communicate findings visually, numerically, and verbally
  6. Apply Scientific Models and Theories - Use established scientific concepts and formulas in context
  7. Use Probability and Statistics - Analyze data sets statistically and determine probabilities

docs.title: Content Domains
docs.text:
• Life Science (40%) - Human body and health, energy flows in ecosystems, cellular organization, heredity, and evolution
  • Physical Science (40%) - Energy conservation and transformation, work and motion, chemical properties and reactions
  • Earth and Space Science (20%) - Earth systems interactions, atmospheric and oceanic characteristics, cosmic structures

docs.title: Focusing Themes
docs.text:
All content is organized around two cross-cutting themes:

  1. Human Health and Living Systems - Topics vital for health and safety of living things
  2. Energy and Related Systems - Sources, transformations, and uses of energy

docs.title: Assessment Approach
docs.text: The GED Science Test balances: - Deeper conceptual understanding - Procedural skill and fluency - Application in realistic situations - Multiple Depth of Knowledge (DOK) levels with 60% at DOK level 2 or 3

docs.title: Target Audience
docs.text: Adult learners preparing for the GED Science Test who need to demonstrate college and career readiness in scientific reasoning and content knowledge.

docs.title: Educational Use Recommendations
docs.text:
• Use taxonomy categories for color-coding in graph visualizations
  • Design curriculum modules based on taxonomy groupings
  • Create filtered views for focused learning paths
  • Use categories for assessment organization
  • Enable navigation by topic area in interactive tools

docs.title: GED Science Assessment Framework
docs.text:
MicroSim placeholder. Interactive visualization to be added.

This MicroSim illustrates the GED Science assessment framework, including science practices and content topics.

docs.title: Learning Graph Viewer
docs.text: This interactive viewer allows you to explore the learning graph for GED Science with all 200 concepts and their dependencies.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Search: Type in the search box to find specific concepts
  • Category Filtering: Use checkboxes to show/hide concept categories
  • Interactive Navigation: Click and drag to explore, scroll to zoom
  • Statistics: View real-time counts of visible nodes and edges

docs.title: Using the Viewer
docs.text:
1. Search for Concepts: Start typing in the search box to find concepts. Click on a result to focus on that node.

  2. Filter by Category: Use the category checkboxes in the sidebar to show or hide groups of related concepts. Use "Check All" or "Uncheck All" for bulk operations.

  3. Navigate the Graph:

  4. Drag to pan around the graph
  5. Scroll to zoom in and out

  6. Click on a node to select it and highlight its connections

  7. View Statistics: The sidebar shows counts of visible nodes, edges, and foundational concepts.

docs.title: Graph Structure
docs.text:
• Foundational Concepts: Prerequisites with no dependencies (shown in red)
  • Advanced Concepts: Topics that build on multiple prerequisites
  • Edges: Arrows point from a concept to its prerequisites

docs.title: Categories
docs.text:
The learning graph includes 9 taxonomy categories:

Category Description Foundation Concepts Core scientific reasoning and methodology Comprehension Reading and understanding scientific text Investigation Design Experimental design and methodology Reasoning from Data Drawing conclusions from evidence Evaluating Conclusions Assessing scientific claims Scientific Theories Major scientific theories and laws Expression of Information Communicating scientific findings Probability & Statistics Statistical concepts and probability Life Science Biology and life science concepts

docs.text: Open Learning Graph Viewer
